LymphTree.title: Starting General Information
LymphTree.content:
Aim of the present algorithm: to guide the physician to the correct clinical approach to lymphoadenopathies (LAP).

Rationale: the diagnostic reasoning is based on anamnestic information and physical findings: their accurate exploitation – under the guidance of a wide clinical knowledge and bed-side experience – can make the diagnostic path more direct, short and, ultimately, cheap.

The first assessments required for the use of the present application are a few basic data regarding the LAP:

  1. Findings recorded through the physical examination of the patient (to choose his/her most appropriate semeiologic category, see Table 1)
  2. Anatomical site of the swollen node
  3. A number of potentially discriminant anamnestic or concomitant clinical characteristics  worth exploring in sequence.

Related to the anatomical site an important acquisition is the spread of the LAP 

  • Is it localized to a single lymph node or to a group of neighbouring lymph nodes, or to a number of lymph nodes confined to a single region (L)?
  • Or is the LAP systemic, i.e., generalized (G) ?
LymphTree.question: General Information -2

LymphTree.title: Table 1
LymphTree.content:
TABLE 1 - PHYSICAL CATEGORIES

A  Stable result of preceding inflammations.
Lymph node not much swelled, with increased consistence, indolent, not hurting at palpation, mobile with respect to deep and superficial tissues; it is generally found by the patient during shaving or washing. It represents the stable outcome of past, often repeated, inflammations.


B  Inflammatory lymph node.
Consistence is reduced, nodules are rather tender and elastic, moderately or heavily aching, with pain increasing at palpation; the skin covering and surrounding the nodule is reddish, sometimes a few, contiguous, inflammatory lymph nodes during their growth tend to agglomerate. Often a lymphangitic stripe connets the swollen node to the site of infection. Fluctuation is rarely possible.


C  Neoplastic lymph node.
Consistency is decisely increased, more heavily in case of involvement by carcinomas or sarcomas rather than by lymphomas, but differences are very slight for a clear discrimination; they are poorly to not aching at all, independent of palpation, mobility is reduced, especially over deep tissues, surface of the swelling mass is lumpy as the result of a coalescence of multiple nodes ; rarely, nowadays, the skin over the node ulcerates.
LymphTree.question: Physical Categories

LymphTree.title: Note
LymphTree.content:
Of course, we must consider the possibility that what at any given moment appears to be a localized LAP is going on to become generalized after a few days, so that one or more physical examinations are necessary after variable time.

Most of the relationships pointed out are probabilistic, and not deterministic. A few others are proposed for completeness of investigation, serving as a reminder of some rare conditions.

The wide availability of soft tissue ultrasonographic scan (US) often allows an early, suitable and accurate verification of the palpatory findings, in particular related to the discrimination between inflammatory or neoplastic involvement.
Thus, the discriminating US aspects are described here (see Table 2), since US has to be considered as a frequent, easy and useful complement of the clinical examination.

IMPORTANT NODES

Type-A lymph nodes will not be considered in the present flow-chart: in most of the cases the determining illness remains unknown and this group of patients require only some physical and ultrasonographic controls along time.

Type C generalized LAP  has not been treated since its diagnostic target relies primarily on the surgical biopsy of one of the swollen lymph node.

LymphTree.title: Table 2
LymphTree.content:
TABLE 2  -  DISCRIMINATORY  ULTRASONOGRAPHIC  (US)  FINDINGS

                         Type C LAP  (inflammatory)

  • the swollen lymph node maintains an oval shape
  • the normal rate between major and minor axis is saved (≥ 2)
  • vascular hilum is recognizable,
  • the vascular-fatty stria is visible, set along the major axis
  • cortex is slightly hypoecogenic.

   
                        Type C LAP (neoplastic)

  • globular shape,
  • vascular hilum and vascular-fatty stria not recognizable,
  • diffuse hyperechogenicity.
LymphTree.question: Ultrasonographic Findings

LymphTree.title: Three steps for the start of investigation
LymphTree.content:
Practically, the application of the present flow-chart can be performed in three steps

First, you have to choose the semeiologic cathegory to which the LAP under examination belongs: B or C (see Table 1) The aid of an US scan whould be very helpful in this assessment. (see Table 2); with this step you realize if you are probably searching for a tumor rather than an infectious or an inflammatory disease.


Second, you must choose the grade of clinical spread reached by the LAP under evaluation (i.e., localized [L] or generalized [G])


Third, the combined information from step 1 and 2 will determine the starting point of your investigation along the flow chart. You must examine each step of the flow-chart very carefully, interpreting the answers (y = yes; n = no) to the offered questions as suggestions or clues endowed with high probability, not as absolute statements.

Remember: the correctness of the clinical procedures – not of the diagnosis – is guaranted by this flow-chart


At the bottom of most of the next pages you will find an essential information on the laboratory and instrumental tests needed to confirm the diagnosis (D), and on the principal drugs utilized in the therapy of the diagnosed ill (T).

LymphTree.title: Start

LymphTree.content:
Semeiologic findings A B B C C
  | | | | |
Spread of the LAP L or G L G L G

LymphTree.title: LAP WITH UNDOUBT CHARACTERISTICS "C" ?
LymphTree.question: LAP with characteristic "B" or doubt "C":  Localized or Generalized ?

LymphTree.title: Category C, Generalized
LymphTree.content: Not Analyzed

LymphTree.title: Category C - Localized LAP
LymphTree.content:
The anatomical areas whose lymph is drained through the swollen lymph nodes under examination – with characteristics 'C'– must be carefully evaluated to identify the probable origin of the tumor. To this aim the main guide of the physical examination is the knowledge of the specific distribution of the regional lymphatic vessels. Surgical biopsy is mndatory.


Occipital / retrocervical
Scalp, outer ear, skin of the neck


Cervical
Orbital tissues, middle ear, nose, skin of face and neck, paranasal sinuses, salivary glands, nasopharinx, tonsils, hyopharynx, larynx, thyroid, upper esophagus


Supraclavear, Mediastinal Retroperitoneal
Bronchi, pleura, breasts, esophagus, stomach pancreas, kidneys, colon, internal genitals, skin of the whole trunk


Axillary
Breasts, bronchi, skin of the arm and upper trunk


Inguinal
External genitals, rectum, anus, skin of legs and perineum

LymphTree.title: Category A
LymphTree.content: Not Analyzed
LymphTree.question: Final node

LymphTree.title: LAP "B"  "L"  -  Site Indifferent
LymphTree.content:
Possible causes:

- Any type of cutaneous wound (lacerated and contused, knife cut, abrasion, burn, crushing)

- Foruncle                                    - Bug bite                                - Erysipelas

- Dermatopathic lymphoadenopathy (due to manyf different skin diseases, mainly esfoliative or eczematoid dermatitis and viral infections in immunodeficent patients            

- Rat-bite fever, with viral-like symptoms, by Streptobacillus Moniliformis or Spirillum Minus (Sodoku) living in the mouth of wild rats, mice, hamsters and squirrels                  

- Necrotizing LAP (Kikuchi's disease, see "Axillary LAP")

- Endemic, nonvenereal, chronic, tropical spirochetosis (or treponematosis) What(or treponematosis) due to body contact in condition of poor hygiene:                                                                                                                   - Beyel, mucocutaneous  lesions due to Treponema Pallidum                                                                                                                                                                                                     - Framboesia (or Yaws): cutaneous lesions and periostitis caused by Treponema Pallidum pertenue                                                                                                                                   - Pinta, with skin lesions only  due to Treponema Pallidum carateum
LymphTree.question: Choose the appropriate localized site of a LAP "B"  or consider the localized site of a LAP "C"

LymphTree.title: Lice (1); Dandruff; Ringworm; Seborrhea
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

 

1, 2   D:  Scratch scalp excoriations: Lice  found at the back of the hair and behind the ears.

         T:  Sensibility to Malathion permethrine and Lindane

 

3, 4  T:  Shampoo with one or more of the following substances: sulfur, salicylic acid, tar, selenium sulfide, zinc pyrithione

              Lotion with 0.01% fluocinolone acetonide or 0.025%  triamcinolone acetonide
LymphTree.question: Recent stay in tropical Countries ?

LymphTree.title: African Trypanosomiasis
LymphTree.content:
Final diagnosis

 

African Trypanosomiasis (also named Winterbottom's disease). The Winterbottom's sign is actually the bulky occipital LAP often present). Due to Trypanosoma gambiense or Treponema rhodesiense transmitted by the bite of hematophagous flies.

To be distinguished from American Trypanosomias (also named Chagas' disease)

D:  m-t;  m-b;  m-lnb (microscopic picture common to Piringer Kuchinga 's adenitis)

T:  suramin;  pentamidine;  melarsoprostol
LymphTree.question: Contacts with cats ? Rav meat eating ?
Contact with cats ? Rav meat eating ?

LymphTree.title: Toxoplasmosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

 

Toxoplasmosis (Toxoplasma Gondi)

 *   Congenital type

 *   Acquired type:

           Lymph nodal disease

          Exanthematic disease

 

D:  Ab-t;   rarely: m-t;   m-lnb  (Piringer Kuchinka adenitis)

T:  pyrimethamine + sulfadiazine
LymphTree.question: Macular Erythema ?

LymphTree.title: Diagnosis not reached
LymphTree.content:
Diagnosis not reached ?

Perform a strict follow-up;  apply also the steps of cervical LAP to occipital one;   consider  m-lnb

LymphTree.title: Rubella (1)   Exanthema Subitum (2)
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

Rubella (German measles)                         Exanthema Subitum  (pseudo rubella)  In infants or very young children  (virus  HHV6;  rarey HHV7 )

 

(1) D:     Clin;    Evolution of IgM serum concentration;    m-b    (infectiousness from 5 days before to 8 days after LAP)    

(1) T:     Symptomatic   Vaccination whenever possible

 

(2) D:      Clin c-b;  PCR;  m-lnb (rarely needed)

(2) T:      Symptomatic;    Fosc. or Ganc in immunosoppressed patients

 

Diagnosis not reached ? Consider strictly follow-up, apply the steps of cervical LAP ;   consider  m-lnb

LymphTree.question: Sudden rise of a nodule or swelling of a pre-existing minor nodule ?
[A]  LAP subauricular, or under jaw angle, or before sternocleidomastoid muscle ?
[B]  LAP on the midline from hyoid bone and thyroid?

LymphTree.title: Branchial cyst
LymphTree.content:
Final diagnosis

Derivation  from the II (A) or III-IV (B) embryological arches. 

T.    Surgery

LymphTree.title: (1) Sarcoidosis;  (2) Herfordt’s Syndrome
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) D:      Transbronchial m-lnb        m-bw: CD4 / CD8 > 3.5        Elevated  Ca and ACE serum levels          Positive whole blood Gallium scan

(1) T:       Predn  0,3 - 1 mg/kg (related to symtoms and/or in absence of spontaneous regression)

                MTX 2,5 mg / week to unresponsive patients

 

(2).    Also known  as " uveoparotid fever" =  uveitis + bilateral parotid swelling + facial palsy + chronic fever

LymphTree.title: Tracoma
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

Chlamydia Trachomatis is transmitted by eye-to-eye or hand-to-eye contacts or eye-seeking flies.

Consequences: entropion, lacrimal duct obstruction, corneal scarring

D:       Clin (early, through follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva)

T:       Azi,       Doxy p.o.;  Tetra or Erythr p.o. and/or ophtalmic gutt ointment

LymphTree.title: American Tripanosomiasis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

Periorbital lesions mark the early phase of the disease (also named Chagas' disease) 

Transmission of the Chlamydia Trachomatis  by Tiatominae bug  bites  (reservoir: dogs, cats, squirrels, bats)

Frequent initial signs: periorbital skin lasion or edema (Romaña’s Syndrome)

D:     Acute phase: m-b;  m-lna       Chronic phase or latent disease: Ab-T;     

        Xenodiagnosis (detecting PCR amplified parasite DNA in patient's blood)

T:     Nif;     benznidazole

LymphTree.question: Exanthem + bright red coating of tongue ?

LymphTree.title: Scarlet Fever
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:    Clin;    c-b;   Antistreptolysin-O titre

T:     Pen;    Cefdn;     Azi

LymphTree.question: Is exudate spreading outside the tonsils ?

LymphTree.title: (1) Mononucleosis;  (2) Cytomegalovirosis;  (3) Listeriosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) D:    Heterophil Ab;     hummer                                

(1) T:   Symptomatic;    (fosc)

                                                          

(2) D:   CMV antibodies 

(2) T:    Ganc;   fosc

 

 (3) D:      c-b;  c-l

 (3) T:     Ampi;      Genta;      Erythr

LymphTree.title: Infection by Adenovirus, Influenza virus, Parainfluenza virus
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:     c-sp;   m-lna;  c-e;   m-b

T:     Symptomatic
LymphTree.question: Tendential slow spread of the LAP ?

LymphTree.title: Diphteria
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D.     Clin;         m-T (gram staining);      c-e

T.     Diphteria antitoxin + Pen,      Erythr

LymphTree.title: Streptococcal Pharyngitis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:     Clin;    c-e;    m-b

T:     Benz-Pen;      Cefdn;     Erythr

LymphTree.question: Positive tuberculin skin test (Mantoux or PPD) ?

LymphTree.title: Cat scratch disease
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:    c-b;    anti-Bartonella Henselae-Ab;   m-lna;    PCR

T:    Cipro,   Gentya,    Doxy,    TMP-SMX

LymphTree.title: Kikuchi’s necrotizing lymphoadenitis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

Cervical or axillary aching LAP in young women, naturally recovering in 1-4 months (due to Yersinia enterocolitica ?)

D.:      m-lnb

T:       Predn;   Ampi

 

 

Diagnosis not reached ?

Retrace the path and considerevery step again as accurately as possible

Explore the possibilityof a neoplastic LAP

Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after a few days

LymphTree.question: Chest RX: result ?
LymphTree.answer1: Negative + LAP of high cervical sites
LymphTree.answer2: Positive + LAP of low cervical sites

LymphTree.title: Scrofula (LAP near the mouth)
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:    Clin + RX;    m-sp;     m-bw

T:    Iso,   Rifa,    Pyraz,    Etham    Scrofula should not be treated with incision and drainage, often resulting in a chronical fistula; 

                                                          if needed, a surgical resection of the whole node must be performed awoiding any wound contamination

LymphTree.title: Active Pulmonary Tubercolosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:     Clin & Radiol;      m sp;     c-sp;   m-bw;    c-bw

T:     Iso;     Rifa;     Pyraz;    Etham

LymphTree.title: Milker Nodule
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:       Clin

T:       No treatment is necessary

LymphTree.title: Pustular Dermatidis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:    Clin

T:    Spontaneous regression is frequent     Locally: ASA, trichloroacetic ac,   Cantharidin

LymphTree.title: Kavasaki's disease
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

Vasculitis of children and teenagers (conjunctivitis,  fever, mouth lesions, LAP, truncal exanthem + coronary artery aneurisms in 29%)

D:    Clin;    ANA + RF;    ESR AND PCR elevated

T:    IgG iv + ASA

LymphTree.title: Herpes simplex conjunctivitis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

Herpes Simplex Conjunctivitis

D:     Clin

T:     Ganc

LymphTree.title: Parinaud’s oculo-glandular syndrome
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

 

LAP + conjunctivitis in Cat-scratch Disease 

D:     c-bal;  c-lna  (Bartonella Henselae)

T:     Cipro,   Genta,   Doxy,     TMP-SMX

LymphTree.title: Listeriosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

 

Listeria monocytogenes is in world-wide dust of fecal origin (from mammals, arachnids crustaceans)

D:    c-b;    c-I

T:    Ampicillin + aminoglycoside

LymphTree.title: Diagnosis not reached
LymphTree.content:
Retrace the path and consider every step again as accurate as possible.
Explore the possibility of a neoplastic  LAP.
Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after a few days

LymphTree.question: Variety of mouth lesions (ulcer, inflammation, aphthae) ?

LymphTree.title: Caries, Gingivitis,  Glossitis,  Stomatitis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:      Clin  (generally by Inspection)

T:     Mouthwashes

LymphTree.title: Syphilis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:     VDRL;     RPR;    FTA 

T:      Benz-Pen;      Ceftriaxone;     Azi

LymphTree.title: Faringo-Laryngitis and Pneumonia by Mycoplasma Hominis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:      PCR;      m-sp;       m-b

T:       Macrolides

LymphTree.question: Contacts with cats?  Upper limb skin lesions?

LymphTree.title: Cat scratch disease
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:    c-bal;   c-lna (Bartonella Henselae);   m-lna;    PCR

T:    Cipro,   Genta,   Doxy,    TMP-SMX

LymphTree.question: Hunter ? Fur handler ? Farmer ?
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:     c-b (Francisella Tularensis);   c-sp;   m-b

T.:     Strepto,   Genta,   Chloramph,    Doxy
LymphTree.title: Tularemia
Tularemia
LymphTree.content: final diagnosis

LymphTree.title: Vaccine disease
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:    Clin

T:    CST

LymphTree.question: Contact with flowers, musk, ornamental plants? Miscellaneous cutaneous injuries, nodules, pustules?

LymphTree.title: (!) Sporotrichosis;  (2) Nocardiosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) :    c-b;   c-lna  (Sporotrix Schenkey)               

T1.:   Itra                                                                     

 

(2) D:   c-b;   c-lna  (Nocardia Asteroides)  

(2) T:    TMP-SMZ

LymphTree.question: Immigration from areas with endemic leprosy ?

LymphTree.title: Plague
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:       c-lna;    c-b;   c-sp  (Yersinia pestis);  Ab-T;   PCR

T:       Strepto;    Doxy;   Chloramph;   Genta

LymphTree.question: Aching LAP in young woman’s axilla ?

LymphTree.title: Kikuchi's disease
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(Cervical or axillary aching LAP in young women, spontaneously recovering within 1-4 months)

D.:    m-lnb;    m-lna  (Yersinia Enterocolitica ?)   

T.:     Predn;   Ampi

LymphTree.title: (Examine the breast):  Mastitis; Elder woman’s telitis;  Post traumatic steatonecrosis;  Mammary thrombophlebitis;  Neoplasia
LymphTree.content:
Diagnosis not reached ?

Retrace the path and consider every step again as accurate as possible

Explore the possibility of a naoplastic LAP

Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after a few days

LymphTree.title: (1) Herpes genitalis;  (2)Chancroid; (3) Lymphogranuloma venereum; (4) Gonorrhea;  (5) Primary Siphilis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) D:    m-les;  c-ce;  Ab-T;  PCR                                                      T:    Acyclovir

(2)D:    m-les (suppurative LAP by Haemophilus Ducreyi)             T:    Azi;    Triax;   Erythr;    Cipro

(3)D:    c-e;  Ab-t                                                                                 T:   Tetra

(4)D:    c-e PCR (Neisseroia gonorrhoeae)                                      T:   Triax;  F-quin;  Oflox;   Spect

(5)D: m-les;  VDRL;  TPH-SMX (ag-t) (Treponema pallidum)       T:   Benz-Pen;  Triax;  Azi

 

All these infections may be the opportunistic counterparts of the HIV infection, which, per se, causes a generalized LAP

LymphTree.question: Stay in, or immigration from, tropical Countries ?
LymphTree.title: INGUINAL  LAP

LymphTree.question: Contact with animals - including pets - parasitized by fleas ?
Coming from areas of sporadic or endemic pestis ?
LymphTree.content: (Endemic pestis areas:  South-west of US and Mexico, equatorial countries of Africa and south of America, Central Asia

final diagnosis

D:     (Yersinia pestis);      c-lna;     c.b;      c-sp;      Ab-T;     PCR

T:        Strepto;     Doxy;    Genta;    Chloramph

LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

T:         Predn;  Rifa;   Ethamb

LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

T:        DECR,    Abend,    Iver

LymphTree.title: Onchocerciasis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

 

D:      m-b;      m-t   (Onchocerca volvulus)

T:     Iver,  Tetra

LymphTree.title: Hilar Mediastinal
LymphTree.question: Hilar LAP ± pulmonary infiltrate ± pleural effusion ?
Stay or immigration from Northern and Central America ?

LymphTree.title: (1) Blastomycosis;  (2)  Coccidioido-mycosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) D:     Chest X-ray;      c-bal;     c-sp

(1) T:      Itra;       Fluco;    Ampho

 

(2) D:     c-l;       c-sp;      c-u;

(2) T:      Fluco;     Ampho

LymphTree.title: Histoplasmosis
LymphTree.content: final diagnosis

LymphTree.question: Contact with pigeons or their escrements ?

LymphTree.title: Cryptococcosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:          c-l;          c-sp;         c-u;    (Cryptococcus neoformans)

T:          Fluco

LymphTree.title: (1) Lymphomas;  (2) Monoclonal gammopathies
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1-2) D:       m-lnb;    (in possible , not: m-lna !);   m-bo

(1-2T):          radio-immuno-chemotherapy

LymphTree.question: Serum T-ly > 20%  and ACE ekevates with Ly T4/T8 > 4 in bronchial washing ?

LymphTree.title: Silicosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D.   Chest X-ray  and/or  chest CT;   m-ln

T.   Corticosteroids

LymphTree.title: Castelman's disease
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:       m-ln

D:      In unicentric Castleman's Dis,:  surgical lymph node removal 

        In multicentric Castleman's Dis: Antivirus (HHV8);   Rituximab;   Chemotherapy

LymphTree.question: Significant skin tests ?  Alcohol- and acid-resistant bacilli in sputum and/or gastrolusis and/or feces ?

LymphTree.title: Diagnosis not reached
LymphTree.content:
Diagnosis not reached ?

Consider alternative hypothesis, possibly arising from thoracic TC and m-bw.

Retrace the path and consider everey step again as accurately as possible

Explore the possibility of a neoplastic LAP

Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after a few days

LymphTree.title: Tubercolosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:     Chest X-ray;     m-sp;     c-sp;     m-gw

T:     Iso;       Rifa;       Pyraz;       Etamb

 

 

 

Diagnosis not reached ?

Retrace the path and consider every step again as accurately as possible

Explore the possibility of a neoplastic LAP

Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after a few days

LymphTree.question: Hilar calcific LAP,  exposure to silica,  pulmonary reticular infiltrates ?

LymphTree.title: Silicosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(Silicosis + reumathoid artriris = Caplan's Syndrome)

(Silicosis + scleroderma = Erasmus' Syndrome

D.   Chest X-ray; 

T. Bronchodilatators; corticosteroids; lung transplant

LymphTree.title: LAP with semeiologic characteristics "C" and generalized anatomic spread ( (G)
LymphTree.question: Cutaneous and/or mucosal bleeding ?

LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) D:     PCR;   Ab-T;     (arbor virus vehicol:ed by Aedes Egypti)

(1) T:     Symptomatic

 

(2) D:     Serum CD4/CD8;   ELISA

(2) T:      HAART;  CT

LymphTree.title: (1) West Nilo Fever;  (2) Ebola and Marburg virus Infections);  (3) Leptospirosis
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) D:    "Breakbone Fever";    PCR;     Ab-T 

(1) T:      Symptomatic and infusive

       

(2) D:     ELISA;  PCR

(2) T:     Symptomatic

    

(3) D:    c-b (Leptospira hicterohemorragiae)

(3)T:     Pen;   Doxy;   Ampi

LymphTree.title: Some aAL and NHL
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

T:         CT;   RT;   IT;

LymphTree.title: Hand-Shuller Christian
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:   m-lnb

T:  Hormone replacement;      RT;      CT

LymphTree.title: (generalized) Chickenpox [varicella]
LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:        m-les;         c-les  (its local reactivation  is named Herpes zoster (shingles), which does not cause generalized LAP)

T:        Symptomatic; oral antivirals

final diagnosis

T:      Amoxi;      Doxy;       Cefur;      Azi

LymphTree.question: Rush as above without vesicles, involving also mucosae ?

LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:   m-b;   m-lna;   PCR

T:    Nif;   Benzn

LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

D:        VDRL;       TPHA;      FTA

T:          Pen;,      Triax,       Azi

final diagnosis

T:        Hormone replacement,         Local Surgery,     RT

LymphTree.question: Transient erythema, confined to the abdomen ?

final diagnosis

final diagnosis

final diagnosis

T;     Therapy of the specific diseases

final diagnosis

D.    Serologic tests

T.    supportive + (B virus):  IF 2 a + lamivudine; 

                          +  (C virus) Sofos + IF + Ribav

final diagnosis

final diagnosis

final diagnosis 

(1) D:       m-b;  m-bo                 

(2) D:      m-bo;   m-pf

LymphTree.title: (1) Polyarteritis nodosa; (2) Systemic sclerosis;  (3) Dermatomyositis;  (4) Rheumatoid arthritis;  (5) Syphilis;   (6) LES;  ( 7) Chickenpox (varicella); (8) Scarlet fever; (9) Tuberculosis; (10) Leptospirosis; (11) Plagues

final diagnosis

(1) D:    Clin;  m-a;       (2) D:   Clin;  ANA; SCL-70        (3) D:  Clin;  m-m;  CK             

(4) D::  Clin;  RA;  anti-CCP           (5) D:     c-ln;  c-b;   c-sp           (6) D:    Clin;  ANA;  ADS-DNA

(7) D:  Clin;  c-d;  Ab-t            (8) D:   Clin;  Ab-t             (9) D:    X-ray;  m-sp;  m-gw; c-sp;        (10) D):  c-b;  serial Ab-t           (11) D:   m-ln;   Ab-t

(1, 2, 3, 4, 6) T:    CST, Immunosoppressors     (5) T:   Benz-Pen;  Triax,  Azi    (7) T:  Ganc        (11) T:  Strepto,   Doxy,  Chloramph,  Genta

(8) T:(9) T:  Iso,  Rifa,  Pyraz,  Etamb    (10) T:   Pen;      Doxy;      Ampi;    Amoxi

LymphTree.title: Spare node
LymphTree.content:
Retrace  the whole path: consider every step as carefully and exhaustively as possibl

Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after some time

LymphTree.title: Diagnosis not reached
LymphTree.content:
Retrace the path and consider every step again as accurately as possible.

Explore the possibility of a neoplastic LAP

Evaluate the patient again and thoroughly after a few days

LymphTree.title: Localized LAP "C"
LymphTree.content:
The anatomical areas whose lymph is drained through the swollen lymph nodes under examination – showing characteristics "C" – must be carefully evaluated, takin into account the specific distribution of the regional lymphatic vessels.

Occipital / Retroauricular:  scalp, outer ear, skin of the neck

Cervical: orbital tisuues, middle ear, nose, skin of face and neck, paranasal sinuses, salivary glands, nasopharynx, tonsils, hypopharynx, larinx, thyroid, upper esophagus

Suplaclavear, Mediastinal, Retroperitoneal: bronchi, pleura, esophagus, stomach, pancreas, kidneys, colon, internal genitals, skin of the whole trunk

Axillary: breasts, bronchi, skin of the arms and upper trunk

Inguinal: External genitals, rectum, anus, skin of legs and perineum

LymphTree.title: Infections by adenovirus;   Cytomegalovirosis;   HIV
LymphTree.content:
Final diagnosis

D:  Ab-t;   m-t;   PCR

T:   Ganc

LymphTree.content:
final diagnosis

(1) D:      m-lnb;    SPET; 

(1) T:      CST,   CT

                                                                 

(2) D:     m-lnb;        

(2 T:)   Surgery;  RT;   CT

         

(3) D: Chest x-ra                 

(3) T: corticosteroids

LymphTree.title: END of the Flow chart
LymphTree.content:
Diagnsis not reached ? 

Retrace the whole path, and  consider every step as detailed and exhaustive as possible.

Evaluate the patient again and thoroghly after some time

Abend Abendazole Fluco Fluconazole Oflox Ofloxacin
Amox Amoxicillin Fosc Foscarnet OH-Cl-quine Idroxychloroquine
Ampho Amphotericin B. Ganc Gancyclovir Penta Pentamidine
Ampi Ampicyllin Genta Gentamycin Predn Prednisone
Azi Azitromycin IF Interferon Pyri Pyrimethamine
BENZ-PEN Benzathine Penicillin G Iso Isoniazide Qui Quinolons
Benzn Benznidazole Itra Itraconazole Riba Ribavirin
Cefd Cefdinir Ivere Ivermectin Rifa Rifampicin
Cefur Cefuroxime Lami Lamivudine Sofos Sofosbuvir
Chloramph Chloramphenicol Lind Lindane Spect Spectinomycin
Cipro Ciprofloxacin Mala-per Malathion Permetrin Strepto Streptomycin
DECR Dietilcarmazepine Mel Melarsogel Sulfga Sulfadiazine
Doxy Doxycicline Mico-M Micophenolate-Mofetil Sur Suramie
Erythr Erythromycin Miglu Miglustat Tetr Tetracycline
Ethamb Ethambutol MTX Methotrexate TRI-SMX Trimethoptim-Sulphametoxazole
F-qui Fluoroquinolon Nif Nifdurtimox

LymphTree.title: TABLE   2  -  ABBREVIATIONS  OF  BIOPSIES  OR  WITHDRAVALS  FOR  MICROSCOPIC  EXAMINATIONS
LymphTree.content:
m-a Artery m-lnb Lymph node surgical biopsy
m-b Blood smears m-puf Periumbilical fat
m-bo Bone marrow biopsy m-rec Rectum
m-gw Gastric washing m-sk Skin
m-le Any type of lesion m-p Sputum
m-K Kidney m-st Stool
m-liv Liver m-t Any type of tissue
m-lna Lymph node aspirate m-thy Thyroid

LymphTree.title: TABLE  3  -  ABBREVIATIONS  OF  CULTUR  TESTS
LymphTree.content:
c-b Blood c-lna Lymph node aspirate
c-bal Bronchioalveolar lavage c-sa Saliva
c-d Dermic material c-skin Skin
c-e Exudate c-sp Sputum
c-jf Joint fluid c-st Stool
c-lx Liquor

LymphTree.title: MISCELLANEOUS   ABBREVIATIONS
LymphTree.content:
Ab-T Antibody titre* G Generalized Presentation
ANA Anti Nuclear Antibodies HAART Highly Active  Antiretroviral Therapy
anti-CCP-Ab Anti Citrullinated Peptide antibodies Ig Immunoglobulin
ASA Acetylsalicylic Acid It Immunotherapy
CT Chemotherapy PCR Polymerase Chain Reaction
Clin Clinical observation PPD Purified Protein Derivative
CST Corticosteroids RA Rheumatoid Arthritis test
CRP C-Reactive Protein RF Rheumatoid Factor
D Diagnostic tests SPE Serum Protein Electrophoresis
ESR Erythrosedimentation Rate T Therapy
FTA Fluorescent Treponema Absorpion  UPE Urine Protein Elewctrophoresis
G Generalized Presentation VDRL Venereal Disease Reseraarch Laborastory

 

(*)    The antibody serum concentration can be determined by many techniques:  Agglutin titre,  Immunoenzymatic test (ELISA),  Western Blot,    Complement fixation,  Radioimmunologic assay,   Latex particle agglutination,   Indirect  immunofluorescence

LymphTree.title: LAP with characteristics "C" and localized "L"
LymphTree.content:
The anatomical areas whose lymph is drained through the swollen lymph nodes under examination – with neoplastic semeiologic characteristics  ("C") must be carefully evaluated, taking into account the specific distribution of the regional lymphatic vessels and  the site of other lymph nodes potentially present along their course.

Occipital / Retroauricular: scalp,  outer ear,  skin of the neck

Cervical / Supraclavear:  prbital tissues,  middle ear,  nose,  skin of face and neck,  paranasal sinuses,  salivary glands,  nasopharynx,  tonsils,  hypopharinx,  larinx,  thyroid,  upper esophagus

Supraclavear / Mediastinal / Retroperitoneal: bonchi,  pleura,  breasts, esophagus, stomach, pancreas, kidneys, colon, internal genitals, skin of the whole trunk 

Axillary / Epithroclear:  breasts  bronchi,  skin of the armsand upper trunk

Inguinal: external genitals,  rectum,  anus,  skin of legs and perineum
